awd_titl_txt: Asymmetric Side Chain Nanodomain-Driven Paracrystallinity Control in Conjugated Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project focuses on understanding and improving the performance of conjugated polymers, a class of materials whose electronic conductivity makes them useful in a wide range of devices across energy generation and storage, biological and chemical sensors, and computation. The electronic performance of these materials is very sensitive to changes in how crystalline they are, and how organized the crystals are; however, there are currently only limited and general strategies to control this crystal organization. To develop new strategies for building this control, researchers at the University of Washington (UW) will produce a series of polymers with a highly controlled chemical structure that is specifically tuned to improve the crystal quality. These polymers will also help to build understanding of the connection between chemical structure and crystal quality, making it easier to predict and design better polymers in the future. Because of the importance of clean energy and interest in the community, this work will be broadly communicated in a number of different places. One major pathway will be through sharing the research lab’s work by demonstrating stretchable solar cells during visitations to classrooms, as well as participating in larger science events such as science and maker fairs, through the UW Materials Ambassadors program. The PI will also work with the UW College of Engineering Math Academy, working with underserved members of the community by providing opportunities for them to participate in research lab work before even graduating from high school. 


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Paracrystallinity in conjugated polymer backbones represents a critical limitation for conjugated polymer electronic conductivity, and current strategies to improve this parameter are currently extremely limited. To address this, researchers at the University of Washington seek to develop a new polymer backbone architecture, using an alternating pattern of polar and nonpolar side chains to improve polymer backbone paracrystallinity. Specifically, this work proposes to use the self-segregation of polar and nonpolar side chains to produce a polymer with high side-chain crystallinity. This polymer will then be processed using a variety of solvent and thermal processing conditions, to control the extent of side chain crystallinity. The effect on backbone paracrystallinity will be measured and correlated with the processing conditions and side-chain crystallinity. This correlation will build understanding of the interconnection between crystallizable side chains and the backbone paracrystallinity, and offer insight into the strategy of using side chain organization as a tool for improving the backbone paracrystallinity. The work will begin with polythiophene backbones but will be expanded to include fused rings and donor-acceptor copolymers. By delving into not just the side-chain self-segregation, but also the connection between processing conditions, side-chain crystallinity, and paracrystallinity, this research will provide a strategy to improving the performance of conjugated polymers. 
.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project "Asymmetric Side Chain Nanodomain-Driven Paracrystallinity Control in Conjugated Polymers," led by Christine K. Luscombe and David S. Ginger at the University of Washington, focused on developing new methods to control paracrystallinity in pi-conjugated polymers. The primary goal was to reduce paracrystallinity to improve the performance of these materials in electronic applications. This summary highlights the key achievements and impacts of the project.

Intellectual merit

The project aimed to develop a new methodology for controlling paracrystallinity in pi-conjugated polymers through self-segregation of highly ordered polar and nonpolar side-chain nanodomains. The research began with poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) and extended to other conjugated polymers like benzodithiophene (BDT) for a broader understanding. The main objectives included:

  1. Developing synthesis and polymerization conditions for controlled synthesis of polar-nonpolar periodic copolymers.
  2. Investigating different methods and crystallization conditions to produce high-quality crystal structures.
  3. Adjusting side-chain chemical structures to influence crystal self-segregation.
  4. Extending the methodology to polymers with extended pi-conjugation systems.
  5. Generalizing the methodology to more complex conjugated polymer systems.
  1. Polymerization Kinetics: The team studied the polymerization kinetics of various thiophene monomers using Kumada catalyst-transfer polymerization (KCTP). They measured reactivity ratios and polymerization rate constants, finding that certain monomers exhibited different reactivity, which is crucial for designing and predicting copolymer structures.
  2. Synthesis of Asymmetric Polythiophenes: The project successfully synthesized asymmetric polythiophenes with alternating hexyl and glycol side chains. It was discovered that polymerization of the glycolated monomer was extremely fast and uncontrolled, likely due to the coordination of side-chain oxygen atoms with lithium or magnesium or a radical-mediated pathway.
  3. Microstructure and Morphology Characterization: Using techniques like Grazing Incidence Wide-Angle X-ray Scattering (GIWAXS) and p-polarized Multiple-Angle Incidence Resolution Spectrometry (pMAIRS), the researchers characterized the microstructure of polythiophenes. They found that symmetric glycolated polythiophene showed significantly lower charge mobility compared to asymmetric polythiophene due to differences in side-chain alignment.
  4. Polaron Absorption Studies: The study "Polaron absorption in aligned conjugated polymer films" revealed that polaron absorption in P3HT films contradicted conventional adiabatic models, supporting a nonadiabatic model that considers nuclear kinetic energy effects. This finding highlights the need for revised theoretical models to accurately interpret polaron absorption spectra.

Broader impacts

The project provided extensive training opportunities for PhD students, including:

  • Advanced polymer synthesis techniques.
  • Training in characterization methods like GIWAXS, pMAIRS, and Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC).
  • Research methodology and experimental design.
  • Interdisciplinary collaboration with experts in materials science, chemistry, and bioelectronics.
  • Scientific writing and presentation skills.

Advancements in Polymer Synthesis and Characterization: The project developed new insights into the fast polymerization behavior of glycolated polythiophenes, which is crucial for creating new materials with controlled molecular weights and tailored properties. 

Challenges to Conventional Theories: The findings from polaron absorption studies challenge traditional mid-gap state models, necessitating a revision of existing theoretical frameworks to incorporate nonadiabatic effects. This enhances the accuracy of predictions regarding material behavior.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/09/2024
Modified by: Christine K Luscombe
